newsitem.title: USA: Alydaar develops millenium bug software.
newsitem.headline: Alydaar develops millenium bug software.

text.p: Alydaar Software Corp said Monday it had developed a software program that will cut the time it takes to fix "year 2000" programming code problems.

Many older computers and software programs will be unable to process dates correctly after December 31, 1999, often because they are programmed to use only the last two digits of a year. Many will see January 1, 2000, as January 1, 1900.

"Preliminary results...have indicated that our new technology can process at least 100 million lines of source code per week, in addition to testing and rule modifications," said Robert Gruder, Alydaar chairman and chief executive.
The new program builds on Alydaar's existing SmartCode technology and should be released in February, following preliminary tests, a company spokesman told Reuters.

In a statement, Gruder said the firm's "millenium bug" technology can focus on often overlooked technical aspects of Year 2000 programming. These areas include addressing sorts and indexes in programs, handling Year 2000 as a leap year, hard-coded "19s" in the program, and partially-compliant Year 2000 systems, he said.
